Arg.V:
#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk supermin
exit 0

exit 0

#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi

exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: supermin bug fix and enhancement update
Vulnerability.Description: Supermin is a tool for building supermin appliances. These are appliances similar to virtual machines usually around 100KB in size, which get fully instantiated on-the-fly in a fraction of a second when you need to boot one of them. The supermin packages have been upgraded to upstream version 5.1.10, which provides a number of bug fixes and enhancements over the previous version. Within this upgrade, the prelink dependency has been removed from the supermin packages as the prelink utility is not supported on 64-bit ARM architecture. (BZ#1021150, BZ#1093261) This update also fixes the following bugs: Previously, the libguestfs utility had a number of dependencies with RPM packages, which could, for some partners, raise security concerns. In addition, the number of dependencies works against the goal of a minimal, stable, and secure environment. In Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.1, libguestfs dependencies are split into subpackages, and thus only the necessary dependencies are involved. (BZ#1071676) Prior to this update, the supermin packages did not build on the Red Hat Enterprise Linux for POWER, little endian architecture. Consequently, the users of this platform did not have supermin available, which prevented other programs from working. With this update, supermin has been updated to support this platform, and the Red Hat Enterprise Linux for POWER, little endian architecture users now have working supermin packages. (BZ#1125690) Users of supermin are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which fix these bugs and add these enhancements. Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
